The '''Edinger-Westphal nucleus''' supplies [[preganglionic]] parasympathetic fibers to the [[eye]], [[constriction|constricting]] the [[pupil]], [[accommodation reflex|accommodating]] the [[Lens (anatomy)|lens]], and convergence of the eyes. <ref>"eye, human" EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. Encyclopaedia Britannica Ultimate Reference Suite. Chicago: EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica, 2010.</ref>
+
The '''Edinger-Westphal nucleus''' supplies [[preganglionic]] parasympathetic fibers to the [[eye]], [[constriction|constricting]] the [[pupil]], [[accommodation reflex|accommodating]] the [[Lens (anatomy)|lens]], and convergence of the eyes. <ref>"eye, human" EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica. [[Encyclopaedia Britannica Ultimate Reference Suite]]. Chicago: EncyclopÃ¦dia Britannica, 2010.</ref>
It has also been implicated in the [[Mirror_neuron|mirroring]] of pupil size in sad facial expressions. When seeing a sad face, participants' pupils dilated or constricted to mirror the face they saw, which predicted both how sad they perceived the face to be, as well as activity within this region.<ref>Harrison NA, Wilson CE, Critchley HD. (2007). Processing of observed pupil size modulates perception of sadness and predicts empathy. Emotion. 7(4):724-9. PMID 18039039 </ref><ref>Harrison NA, Singer T, Rotshtein P, Dolan RJ, Critchley HD. (2006). [http://www.pubmedcentral.nih.gov/picrender.fcgi?artid=1716019&blobtype=pdf Pupillary contagion: central mechanisms engaged in sadness processing.] Soc Cogn Affect Neurosci. 1(1):5-17. PMID 17186063 </ref>
It has also been implicated in the [[Mirror_neuron|mirroring]] of pupil size in sad facial expressions. When seeing a sad face, participants' pupils dilated or constricted to mirror the face they saw, which predicted both how sad they perceived the face to be, as well as activity within this region.<ref>Harrison NA, Wilson CE, Critchley HD. (2007). Processing of observed pupil size modulates perception of sadness and predicts empathy. Emotion. 7(4):724-9. PMID 18039039 </ref><ref>Harrison NA, Singer T, Rotshtein P, Dolan RJ, Critchley HD. (2006).
